data.title: Feature Request: finer package controls
data.body:
This morning I found I'd updated a package which had been deployed while broken, which meant every time I move my cursor the devtools burst open. It's pretty annoying.

However, the plugin itself is really good, and I don't want to uninstall it. It'd be really handy if the packages page allowed me to roll back to a particular version, or even disable it until a new release is available.

If this is the wrong place for FRs, please close it and point me to where I need to go :)

data.title: Drag tabs between windows results in untitled tab.
data.body:
So, in my attempt to work around the current fact that opening a file opens a new window, I figure I could drag that file from the new window into the original window that I had open.  Turns out that doesn't work.  I get a new tab in the old window that is empty and untitled.  The original tab in the "new" window disappears.

I was using atom 2f82fb2ceb5501f2df7e839af467fbfd4bec47ad, on ubuntu 14.04 32-bit.

data.title: Upgrade to Chrome 35
data.body:
This PR upgrades atom-shell to 0.14 which is based on Chrome35, and also updates modules to make them compilable with node v0.11.13.

All node modules and atom packages that rely on native modules had been bumped a major version to avoid version conflicts before this PR gets merged.

data.title: Don't write .deb files in place
data.body:
Previously running `sudo script/grunt install` followed by `script/grunt mkdeb` would result in an error since the file created at `resources/linux/Atom.desktop` would be owned by root.

Now the control and desktop files are never written to the source tree and instead always written to the build folder and copied over.

Refs #2129

data.title: Clicking file quickly opens the file twice
data.body:
If you click the same entry in the tree view a second time before the first one opens, it will open two editors for that file.

Noticed this while testing a slow network drive on Windows but it isn't Windows specific since it can happen whenever loading a file is slow.

data.body: When i open a file with atom editor and try to insert the "@" symbol the editor does a horizontal text alignment instead of inserting the "@" symbol

data.title: Proper Linux second clipboard support
data.body:
CC: #2272 #2244

My implementation follows the traditional X11 behaviour as closely as possible:
1. The main clipboard (Ctrl+C, Ctrl+V) is a different one than the second one (select, middle-click) which I'm implementing here. That means, by copying to one, the second one is left intact.
2. When pasting, the text cursor goes to a position under the mouse, then the second clipboard data are pasted (ie. it ignores and overwrites the previous cursor position and selection).
3. When copying, text is copied to the second clipboard only if I select the text with a mouse (not with a keyboard, not if the text is selected with some kind of automatic behaviour). This also includes double-click and triple-click selection.
4. When I deselect the text (this is why I check the length), the second keyboard is left intact.
5. The second clipboard should work between applications.
6. The paste should take place on mousedown, not on mouseup.

data.title: Collapsing code causes issues with right-arrow navigation
data.body:
Windows 8.0, Atom v0.115.0, occurs in safe mode

To replicate: open a file (confirmed in php and js files), collapse a relatively good sized code block and move cursor below the collapsed block; now attempt to use the right arrow to navigate to the end of various longer lines of code/text.

The cursor stops in seemingly arbitrary places, and not in the same column of each line. Some lines might not allow right arrow navigation at all, some might do it all the way to the default 80 char line guide, generally somewhere in between though.

Not seeing any errors in dev tools console.

[See here for video.](http://discuss.atom.io/t/collapsing-code-causes-issues-with-right-arrow-navigation/10932/3?u=rosseyn)

data.title: Cursor disappears after changing keyboard layout using a custom shortcut.
data.body:
This happens on Ubuntu 14.04. I have set the shortcut for changing the keyboard layout to `ctrl+shift+space`. When pressing these buttons the cursor disappears. It can be restored by clicking on the editor. Also, when using this shortcut, some accents (in French) don't work until the file is saved once. 

This is most likely related to https://github.com/atom/atom/issues/2122. However I find it interesting that in this case the `alt` key is not used to cause this issue. It seems that Atom doesn't play well with certain Unity keyboard shortcuts.

Build number is 2bd8015a9d69bbc4dd4b7c8f32848073b458a182. I am also using the React editor.

data.title: Opening several large files makes atom unresponsive
data.body:
If this is a duplicate please disregard:

If I open several large files atom becomes unresponsive.
After i am prompted with the force close dialog then i can close it.
When i open it again in the same path the previously open files are opened again, which causes atom to become unresponsive again.

The files are some browserified js bundles.
I think they are prerendered even if the tab does not have focus which makes the editor freeze - that would be my best guess.

The workaround i found is to delete the files from disk and opening the files again(atom .) .
I mainly use atom from the command line call using atom . to open the current folder and the files in it.

data.title: Update Windows build instructions
data.body:
Just a few suggested changes to reflect experiences over a few months of building on several Windows machines.
- The Posix tools comment doesn't seem to be applicable (anymore)? 
- Added further instructions when using pre-installed Git.
- Added the frequent issue of first-time build failures (random `node-gyp` errors), which don't reoccur on second try.
- Added a few extra words on opening a new issue, to clarify that appropriate details should be provided, if the issue hasn't been reported before.

Feel free to amend or suggest further changes.

data.title: Chromium's font rendering color inaccurate
data.body:
Font rendering in Chromium has a problem: the color is inaccurate. While it's not serious for a web browser, it's serious for a code editor. I was so frustrated when writing a syntax theme. Can GitHub do something to tweak Chromium's font color to what it should be?

To show everybody the problem, I made a comparison between 3 browsers. First, take a look at 13px font in Chrome (same effect as Atom). Left is black, right is rgb(0,128,0) green:
![chrome-008000-13](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/731796/3636927/84ec4c5e-0fe9-11e4-9030-3946b770c852.png)

It's a little darker. What's the correct color? Let's take a look at Firefox and Safari's:

Firefox:
![firefox-008000-13](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/731796/3636952/16ee5862-0feb-11e4-924a-531b0da204ab.png)

Safari:
![safari-008000-13](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/731796/3636953/21753de6-0feb-11e4-94e8-95ea1506f344.png)

Chromium has a -webkit-font-smoothing css property, set to "subpixel-antialiased" by default. If changed to "antialiased", it becomes too bright:
![chrome-008000-13-antialiased](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/731796/3636964/4ad44d5c-0fec-11e4-879b-04560558416e.png)

My conclusion is: whatever smoothing strategy I choose, it's inaccurate. Either too dark or too bright. It will become more serious if the font is even smaller.

Let's look at an extreme case (8px using default smoothing. not practical, just to show the problem):
![chrome-008000-8](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/731796/3637003/1c362b0c-0fef-11e4-8820-5680288feb41.png)
In Chrome it became completely black.

Firefox:
![firefox-008000-8](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/731796/3637018/de517a02-0fef-11e4-9a9d-42d65e6a1976.png)

Safari:
![safari-008000-8](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/731796/3637019/e6e1e012-0fef-11e4-8ea0-df4ac245ec95.png)

Before my test, I thought it's a Webkit problem, but now I tend to think it's a Chromium problem, because Safari is OK.

Update:
Seems it's caused by anti-aliasing. If you set `-webkit-font-smoothing` to `none`, then the color is correct, but the font looks ugly. Maybe Webkit has some internal parameters that control the anti-aliasing, but Chromium did not tune it to its best? That's why Safari's font color is OK? I don't know.

Update:
If React editor is enabled (default in v0.117), then it will be too bright rather than too dark.

data.title: Atom crashes when opening files
data.body:
I've got an issue with Atom on OSX. Every time I attempt to open a file, a gray window appears and behind it a dialogue that reads "The editor has crashed Please report this issue to atom@github.com" appears behind it. (The file never opens).

This issue started when I attempted to open a file that did not appear immediately. I thought perhaps the window had opened underneath the current window that I was looking at, so I entered OSX's "Mission Control." While I was in Mission Control, the new Atom window appeared as a gray window over Mission Control. I exited Mission Control and the Atom window remained gray. I was unable to close that window and the editor was unresponsive so I force quit it. After that, all subsequent attempts to open any file in atom resulted in the gray window problem.

Starting Atom in safe mode seems to solve the problem, but I have no external packages installed, so it must be one of the packages that ships with Atom that is causing the problem.

WindowServer[90]: _CGXGetWindowOrderingGroup: Invalid window 0xffffffff

data.title: Editing Chromium Flags
data.body:
I have tried looking _really_ hard, and I just can't find any information on how to edit Chromium flags. I tried editing a bunch of files and reverting after each individual change that didn't work (i.e. the scientific method). I have yet to find the proper way for setting flags for Chromium to handle. I am serious, I may have spent an hour fiddling with the code trying to get it to work.

Can someone help me out and just tell me exactly what I need to do in order to add the flag `--enable-direct-write` to Chromium? Thanks a ton! _Also, I'm really sorry if this is the incorrect location for this, but I wasn't sure where else to go!_

data.title: Upgrade keymap to support 'abort!' directive in keybindings
data.body: Closes atom/vim-mode#348. See that issue for more explanation.
